thread.title: Copper, Aussie Nurse Losses on China; Asian Stock Futures Mixed
thread.title_full: Copper, Aussie Nurse Losses on China; Asian Stock Futures Mixed - Bloomberg Business

author: Bloomberg.com
title: Copper, Aussie Nurse Losses on China; Asian Stock Futures Mixed
text:
Crude oil to copper nursed a hangover with commodity-linked currencies, while Asian index futures were mixed after evidence of the weakest Chinese growth since the global financial crisis rekindled anxiety over the slowdown there.
U.S. crude lingered below $47 a barrel and copper futures fell for a third day with the data showing a pullback in Chinese expansion stoking concern over demand for raw materials. The Australian and New Zealand dollars maintained losses from Monday, with both currencies regarded as bellwethers for China given their trading links. Japanese index futures rose, while shares in Sydney fell with contracts on Chinese stocks.
China had an outsized impact on financial market sentiment last quarter, and Monday's 3Q GDP data proved a reminder.
“The key question for investors is how much can growth accelerate in the December quarter and will there be more policy stimulus,” Matthew Sherwood, head of investment strategy at Perpetual Ltd. in Sydney, which manages about $21 billion, wrote in an e-mail to clients. “The answer to both questions is - not a lot. I still believe that within three years official Chinese growth will have a five handle in front of it and if deflation pressures on the corporate sector persist, one could be more confident that financial stresses will only build over this time.”
While U.S. stocks seemed to shrug off the data, Asian equities ended Monday lower. The region’s largest economy grew 6.9 percent last quarter from a year earlier, exceeding the 6.8 percent rate projected by economists but below the government’s official target for 2015 of 7 percent. With China the world’s biggest consumer of industrial metals and a key oil importer, a Bloomberg gauge of commodity prices slid the most in a month. Disappointing earnings from Morgan Stanley fueled concern over bank profit in the U.S., while anxiety over the debt ceiling pushed short-end Treasury bill rates to a seven-month high.
Stocks
Futures on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index lost 0.1 percent by 8:04 a.m. in Tokyo, after the U.S. benchmark added less than 0.1 percent on Monday to remain at an eight-week high as gains in consumer stocks offset losses for commodity producers.
Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index slipped 0.5 percent to snap a three-day advance, while the S&P/NZX 50 Index in Wellington gained 0.5 percent in an eighth day of gains, its longest rally since November last year.
Nikkei 225 Stock Average futures were bid up by 0.7 percent in the Osaka pre-market, to 18,260, while yen-denominated contracts on the Japanese gauge fell 0.1 percent. Japan’s larger Topix index retreated 0.7 percent Monday, helping drive a 0.3 percent decline in the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. The yen, which typically moves at odds with Japanese shares, was little changed for a second day, trading at 119.51 per dollar.
While futures on the Kospi index in Seoul added 0.1 percent in most recent trading, those on Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index were down 0.3 percent. Contracts on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, a gauge of mainland stocks listed in the city, dropped 0.4 percent. FTSE China A50 Index futures slipped at least 0.5 percent with those on the CSI 300 Index.
The Reserve Bank of Australia releases minutes of its October meeting Thursday, while Japan reports on machinery tool orders and department store sales. Sri Lanka reviews interest rates.
Futures on Taiwan’s Taiex gauge climbed 0.2 percent before details of a potential merger between SanDisk Corp. and Western Digital Corp., both makers of data storage, emerged after U.S. markets closed. SanDisk is in advanced talks to sell itself to Western Digital, with 2015 a record year for semiconductor mergers and acquisitions.
Semiconductor and semiconductor equipment manufacturers make up more than 24 percent of the Taiex, according to index weightings calculated by Bloomberg.
